author: A_Brickset_user
title: Marvellous set
review: Adventurers is the most entertaining of the themes and this set has added more hours of fun to my collection. My 3-year-old son is intrigued by the warning hieroglyphic on the tomb - that attention to detail is what makes LEGO so special and this set is full of such nice flourishes.

author: mrmitch
title: Cleaver set design at a great price
review: This set helped fuel my passion to be a LEGO collector. The pulling of the spear makes a black chain raise the top of the crypt to reveal the skelton. You get a tree, skelton with rare head dress Johnny and Sinister. Cool piece with the drawings on them. The treasure is hidden in a neat location but I am not going to give it away. BUY THIS SET IF YOU GET THE CHANCE.

author: hustla187
title: Just Perfect in Every Way
review: I got this set on Christmas Day in 1999. I really liked this set alot. The tomb is just fantastic with the cat-like statue on top and the chain that opens it up. The palm tree is also a great feature of this set. The mummy isn't bad either. This should be the best Desert set ever made.

author: smiley905
title: very good and works like it should
review: this set works great, you pull the spear and the lid moves up to reveal a skeliton! ououh! scary. well, its pretty cool. it comes with great peices and a palm tree which rocks. the jackle is simple but looks fine, you can tell what it is easy, and the treasure chest in it is very cool. this is like my favorite egipt set i got, its awsome, and one of the highest rated sets on brickset

author: skyscraper
title: Great peices!
review:
I really loved this set, I got it for cheap to. You get a plam tree a skelleton and working tomb that opens its perfect!Get it if you find it ( Iwas luck that I got it for cheap.

pros
skeleton
kind tut head gear
jonny thunder
sam sinister
cool looking tomb
opening device
plenty of weapons 
plam tree

cons 
ZIPO!

author: legoman4694
title: yet another 5
review: this set is awesome. i got it for 99 cents on ebay and it was worth more. there are a lot of cool hyrogliphic parts and i noticed there is a difference in the egypt sets maps. its the only egypt set i have that is not a vehicle. its cool how you pull the spear and the tomb opens up only to reveil a skeleton. the actual treasur is hidden in a chest. the headdress is also cool because its blank (most have stripes). also the back of the box has good alternate models. only 1 question. how many more 5s until it has a perfect 5 on the side?

author: knuclear200x
title: Face Melted by Awesomeness
review:
A lot of the sets I used to own didn't have too many interactive features. Sure I had a lot of cars and that one set with the secret decoding translucent pieces, but this one topped them all. 

The pieces were cool, containing one small brown treasure chest and those delicious looking gold coins...mmm...uh...i mean shiny gold coins...yes...a chain, and a cool bendy palm tree. A lot of nice figures too, we had Johnny Thunder himself, the evil tophat guy who remained nameless to me til today, a scorpion and loose-armed skeleton wearing a pharaoh's headgear. The skeleton wasn't as fun back in the day (in my opinion) because of its loose, unposeable arms. But they changed that years later.

But the main feature of this set was the treasure tomb under the Anubis Statue. I've seen a lot of sets that featured things like catapults that didn't always impress, but this one was just awesome. The chain connects one end of the statue and a spear lever on the other. By simply pulling the lever back, it will open the smoothly placed compartment and reveal the sacred treasure...under the zombie skeleton and scorpion. The two won't pop out at you or anything, but you can imagine it which pretty much is part of the fun. What's even better is that you can play with the compartment over and over and it wont break off til after a long while.

And after you're done with it and have many extra pieces at your disposal, you can take it apart and turn the tomb into a secret base or some kind of protective shelter with laser guns etc. But its up to you.

author: legostarwarsfan
title: Awesome
review:
I love this set. It has really awesome figs and a cool tomb

PROS:
  • Johnny Thunder
  • Sly Boot
  • The tomb opens
  • Treasure
  • Palm tree
  • Rare pharao hood
  • Stickers look cool
  • Scorpion
CONS:
  • NONE

Get this set.

author: absolutelylez
title: One of my favourite sets
review:
PROS
- Great design, with chain used to pull up the tomb
- The adventurers are tricked to look inside (finding a mummy!) and don't see the treasure right in their faces (in the jackal statue!)
- Little palm tree
- Nice simple design

CONS
- The design of the pulley bit makes it easy to break off and that was irritating

author: SaintElsewhere
title: Beware the pharaoh's curse!
review:
This set is quite lovely. The tomb in the middle of the desert is well-executed, with the jackal statue that doubles as a treasure chest; the spear lever that opens the tomb; and the printed tile warning trespassers of the danger that lurks within all serving as prime examples of the detail Lego put into their sets back in the days when "Only the best is good enough" actually meant something.
   The minifigures are great to look at, especially Slyboots, who is dressed rather improperly for the Egyptian desert, with a black dinner jacket and top hat. Johnny Thunder, on the other hand, is a bit more sensible, with an open-collared khaki shirt, a wide-brimmed fedora to protect him from the sun, and a handkerchief in case of dust storms. Then the skeleton has...a headdress. Yay.

Pros:
*hieroglyphs add detail
*scorpion
*jackal-statue/treasure chest is a nice touch
*printed map tile
*palm tree is a nice touch

Cons:
none

author: Chaz777
title: Brilliant set, up there with the best of them
review:
This has always been one of my favourite sets, because, as I said in my review of 6672, you get so much.
I was about four or five when the first adventurers sets came out, and when I first saw them in the catalogue I wanted them badly, but since my birthday was coming up, mum said I could only have one small set at the time, then the two 'big ones' (Sphinx secret suprise and Temple of Anubis) for my birthday. This was the small set I chose.
I certainly wasn't disappointed. This set lasted me for about two months of solid playing and building, which was easy because of the bricks you get. You really do get everything you need for any Egyptian adventuring situation you can think of. The featured model, for a start, which is a nicely designed sarcophagus- type thing, with the statue of Anubis on top concealing the hidden gold coins, and the long-dead priest laying in the main compartment. Which, by the way, opens when you pull the spear lever next to it.
As well as that, you also get the main protagonist of the theme, Johnny Thunder, and the main antagonist, 'Snake boots' (or Lizard boots, as I called him for some reason). And they aren't short of equipment, either, having a weapon each, a revolver and a rifle, and a map which they have to fight over. You also get a palm tree thrown in for good measure, which is on it's own little 4x4 plate piece so you can position it anywhere. 
I also want to talk about the skeleton, which I still like more than the 'What the hell is he wearing' mummy from the larger sets. His headpiece is fairly rare nowadays, and he has a scorpion to protect him, which I thought was pretty cool.
And to top it all off, the alternate models are pretty good, too, with the two hieroglyphic panels and Egyptian warning sign piece making any temple, tower or ruin you like possible.
Oh, and I should mention that the hieroglyphic panels on either side of the sarcophagus are stickers, which would be a con in any other review, but I've never really minded them that much, so in this review they're a pro because they look cool.
So all in all, this is a fine set that is well worth hunting down, either as a counterpart to some of the other Egyptian sets, the start of a new collection, or just because it's a great little set.

author: BasiltheBatlord
title: Oasis Tomb
review:
A great little tomb. There is a lever that can be pulled to open it, and it is topped with a jackal statue. There are some coins and a scorpion, the latter of which can hide in the tomb. There is also a skeleton with a head dress.  The jackal statue can be opened to put the coins inside.

For figs, the set has the skeleton, Sam Sinister with a rifle and pistol, and Johnny Thunder with a map.

author: alosx
title: Part of something bigger.
review:
I bought this set about 10 years ago and i was astonished. Then. By minifigs.

Building experience and playability is nothing much if one does not have some other sets, prefferably of Johnny Thunder. It is a cleaver opening box with standard skeleton in it (pharaoh headpiece is not so standard, but it is nothing to yearn for). Playability is low, because how long one can play around a box? Experience says: not for long. It is a great set with combination with other Johnny Thunder sets, not so good stand alone set. It would give a lot for this set to have some transportation in it: a plane, a car or even a simple motorcycle would do. It really needs it to make it from mediocre set to a great one.

 

Short pros and cons:

pros:

minifigs,

chain,

treasure map.

 

cons:

dull, not great stand alone set,

small and simple (some could consider it a pro)

author: orybloodmyre
title: Fun set, brings back many memories.
review:
I got this set pretty much straight after it came out. I was only 8 at the time but this was a set that remained a favourite for a very long time. I loved the chain opening the tomb up gimmick, and it was a thing I incorperated into my own creations many times afterwards.

 

I had not long studied ancient Egypt at school and was very interested in the subject so was pleased that this came out.

 

At the time I had not watched Indiana Jones, else I probably would have loved these sets even more!

 

I think that although the set is small, it does have quite a bit of playability. It has 3 mini figures, A good guy, a baddie, and a mummy to attack them both, and it has weapons for them all (providing the mummy gets the spear) and a scorpion. I did not have many other sets of this theme as a kid, as I was the sort of kid who would buy from any theme and not be limited to just one, though I did pick up the scorpion tracker car as well which complimented this set nicely.

 

In all this was a small set but was definately fun and cheap as well.

author: KLOKRIECHER
title: LEGO Adventurers (Desert) - Oasis Ambush Review
review:
This is a set which includes a tape with an awsome story for the LEGO Adventurers. This set is really easy to build and it has a sticker on each side of the sarcophagus. It's a very sturdy set and the sarcophagus does open if you pull the spear which is attached by a chain. You can put in the skeleton very nice. On the top of the sarcaphagus is a black dog statue with a black treasure chest where you can hide some gold. You also get a palm tree and another cool map in this set. This set also includes Johnny Thunder who is in many LEGO Adventurers sets. You also get Sly Boots who's a henchman of Sam Sininster.

All in all this set is a good set and I would recommend you to get this. You can find this set on eBay, BrickLink and Amazon for sure. Here is the link where you can check out the full gallery I made for this set on my website: http://www.klokriecher.de


Videos I made of this set:

Stopmotion 1
Stopmotion 2
Stopmotion 3
Review

author: Odeinoichus
title: This is an Oasis?
review:
Set #5938 Oasis Ambush: I think the title of this set is misleading, true it does include a palm tree, but when I hear Oasis I think cool watery shaded place in the middle of arid wastelands, not a dangerous miniature tomb with the skeleton of a dead Egyptian King waiting to spring to life and murder you.

 

This set from the Adventurers theme is one of the small cheap sets released back in the day - it includes three mini-figures, a black scorpion, gold pieces and a treasure chest to put them in. It also includes one palm tree and a scary looking tomb, like I said not an Oasis.

 

Johnny Thunder is the same as we've all seen by now, a LEGO interpretation of an Indiana Jones archetype. He carries a pistol with him in this set and a treasure map marking the location of the tomb.

 

Sam Sinister... That is his name, right? Well he's obviously working with Johnny for the betterment of mankind. Not. This villain of the Adventurers theme is in it for only one thing, the gold, and he carries a rifle just to proove that he can take care of himself.

 

The Skeleton is the older designed version with the floppy limbs, so even though he can hold a weapon or other accessory he can't wield it very well.

 

Building the Oasis part of this Oasis Ambush is fun and relatively short, but it offers up some nice little touches. (In spite of the stickers used for detailing, which still hold up quite well thirteen years later.) The aforementioned stickers give Egyptian Hyrogliphics designs for each side of the miniature tomb, there is a printed plate with instructions on how to open the tomb.

 

This is accomplished by pulling on the spear which pulls the chain which flips open the top of the tomb allowing the skeleton to leap out (with a little help from the one playing with the set.) and scare off the intruders. The clever design of the dog-like statue incorporating the treasure chest as the body is really neat, and evokes a feeling of Egyptian style masonry/carvings.

 

The scorpion just sits in the open visible to all in the instructions, but if you wanted you could easily squeeze him into the treasure chest to protect the gold. After thirteen years my palm tree has only one good frond left, the others are broken or breaking so I'll have to order some replacements one of these days from LEGO Shop At Home. Still if you want some older style bendy palm trees this is a cheap way to get one.

 

All in all I rate this a five, because it's fun, it accomplishes what it sets out to do and it invokes the spirit of the Egyptian Mummy movies from Universal, or even Abbot & Costello Meet the Mummy. The Instructions also showcase alternative models that can be built with the pieces in the set, but you'll have to figure out how to dupliate the photographed models yourself, which is part of the fun of LEGO. Discovery.

author: Cake_Crafted
title: Great little set
review:
This set is really good.

I think the 'legoglyphs' are better then the new ones but the best thing about this model is the added play function of opening the tomb by pulling the spear and revealing the skeleton.The only bad thing about this set is when you have opened the tomb it is really hard to get the skeleton out.

The palm tree is really cool and bends easily when you want it to.

I definitely recommend this set.

author: tadlos61
title: Perfect little set!!
review:
This was my first set from the Adventurers' theme, and I love it!  As a child I spent hours pitting Johnny Thunder and Slyboots against each other.  To this day it remains built; it is perfect for its size and price.  This set encompasses all of the main ideas of the Adventurers' theme.  It has a trap, treasure, nice palm tree, clever design and your good guy, bad guy, and mummy.

Box/Instructions

I love the box art and instructions.  I remember as a child, it really gave the vibe of this little temple being hidden in the middle of the desert.

Parts

Nice parts! The palm tree is wonderful, along with the treasure chest/coins, scorpion, trap door, and a couple of printed pieces (treasure map and hieroglyphs on the 1x4 plate) The hieroglyphs on the side of the tomb are stickers, but they are the decal type, and are still firmly in place 18 years later :)

Minifigures

Perfect selection!  You have your hero, Johnny Thunder, with his map and a revolver, and then the sinister Slyboots with his rifle, and finally the mummy hidden in the tomb, he is my personal favorite.  The mummy looks great with the yellow headdress

The build

A unique build, I had fun building the trap and hidden treasure chest!

The completed model

Very nice little set, looks great! The trap is so fun!  You pull the spear and the trap door opens revealing the mummy!  The hidden treasure on top is awesome too! It perfectly blends into the Anubis/canine statue!

Overall opinion

I would definitely recommend this to anyone interested in the Adventurers' theme, or just anyone wanting to get a taste of what that wonderful theme was all about :)

 

Cheers!

Kyle

author: mafon2
title: The Good, The Bad, and The Rotten Mummy
review:
I remember the time it was bought and the place. It was a gift for good grades. I chose it, because it had many interesting pieces: coins, scorpion, chain, map, rifle and skeleton with nemes. And I loved that it had 2 secrets: black chest, hidden in plain sight as a very appropriate jackal (Upwawet) statue, and mechanism to open the lid of the tomb. It was so simple, but worked really well. I don't know, though, why builders thought it's a necessary thing for a tomb to have.

Also, it has some ideas for alternative assembling. The shrine with chained skeleton has very creepy implications. And the picture of the skeleton in a top hat is self-explanatory.

It's a great little playset that has everything for an adventure. I think it holds up till this day.

***

I managed to find some of it. Mr Sinister Boots was chewed by my dog... a very long time ago...
